useCaseType: Trust & Privacy Negotiation (Sensor Data, Data Sharing)
name: Selective Sensor Data Sharing
description: Olivia exercises strict control over which sensor data ALFRED collects and shares, ensuring her privacy preferences are respected while enabling minimal and secure monitoring to support her recovery.
scenario:
Olivia, a retired social worker with a sharp eye for privacy, sat in her living room staring warily at the ALFRED device. She had reluctantly agreed to use the system to support her recovery but remained deeply skeptical about how much of her personal information it would collect and share. When ALFRED’s voice assistant prompted her to activate the wearable sensors for health monitoring, Olivia quickly interrupted with a firm command to limit data collection. She insisted that only her heart rate and step count be recorded, rejecting any additional sensors that might track more sensitive information. She dismissed ALFRED’s brief explanation of the benefits, preferring not to hear any detailed pitches or justifications.

Olivia’s tone was formal and curt, reflecting her desire to keep interactions strictly professional and to avoid any sense of intrusion. She repeatedly instructed ALFRED to block app installations unless she explicitly requested them, wary of hidden features that might compromise her data. When the system suggested sharing some sensor data with her doctor for better care, Olivia flatly refused, stating she wanted no data shared even with medical staff unless absolutely necessary and always under her direct consent.

Despite ALFRED’s gentle reminders to confirm medication intake or accept video check-ins, Olivia chose to decline, preferring offline updates and visits from her caregivers. She found video calls invasive and was deeply uncomfortable with the idea of constant monitoring. Notifications about strenuous exercises were dismissed outright, as she found them discouraging and intrusive.

Olivia’s daughter, aware of her mother’s privacy concerns but also worried about her health, occasionally checked in by phone, but Olivia was resistant to any overt monitoring. The tension between wanting autonomy and needing assistance was palpable. Olivia’s persistent grumpiness and reluctance to embrace technology were met by ALFRED’s respectful compliance, adapting to her strict boundaries without pushing further. Though the system’s monitoring was minimal, Olivia felt a fragile sense of control restored, allowing her to engage cautiously with the technology on her own terms.
